questions.question_text: What is the primary purpose of a DataRaptor Extract?
questions.explanation: DataRaptor Extract is specifically designed to read and retrieve data from Salesforce. It queries objects and fields and can perform data transformations.

questions.question_text: Which DataRaptor type would you use to update multiple records in a single transaction?
questions.explanation: DataRaptor Load is used for creating or updating Salesforce records. It can handle multiple records in a single operation.

questions.question_text: What does the 'Null Default Value' checkbox do in a DataRaptor?

answers.text: Sets the field to null if no value is provided
Prevents null values from being written
Uses a default value when the source is null
Validates that the field is not null

questions.explanation: The Null Default Value option allows you to specify a default value to use when the source field is null or empty.

questions.question_text: What is the advantage of using a DataRaptor Turbo Extract over a regular DataRaptor Extract?
questions.explanation: DataRaptor Turbo Extract processes data on the server side, resulting in better performance especially with large data sets.

questions.question_text: In a DataRaptor Transform, what is the purpose of the Extract step?

answers.text: To define the input data structure

questions.explanation: In a DataRaptor Transform, the Extract step defines the structure of the input JSON data that will be transformed.

questions.question_text: Which of the following can be used as a data source in a DataRaptor Extract? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: DataRaptor Extract can query Salesforce objects, traverse relationships, and access formula fields. External APIs require HTTP Actions or Integration Procedures.

questions.question_text: What happens when a DataRaptor Load encounters an error during record creation?

answers.text: Only the failed record is skipped
The process continues but logs the error
It depends on the error handling configuration

questions.explanation: By default, DataRaptor Load operations are transactional. If one record fails, all records in the transaction are rolled back.

questions.question_text: In a DataRaptor, what does the 'List' checkbox indicate?

answers.text: The data structure is an array/collection
The field should be displayed as a list

questions.explanation: The List checkbox indicates that the data element represents an array or collection of items, not a single value.

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of the Set Values element in an OmniScript?

answers.text: To display calculated values to the user
To assign values to variables without user interaction

questions.explanation: Set Values allows you to set variable values programmatically without requiring user input, useful for calculations and data manipulation.

questions.question_text: Which of the following are valid OmniScript element types? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Step, Type Ahead Block, and HTTP Action are all valid OmniScript elements. Remote Action is a Visualforce concept, not an OmniScript element.

questions.question_text: What happens when you set an OmniScript element's 'Conditional View' property?

answers.text: The element is shown/hidden based on a condition
The element's value is conditionally required

questions.explanation: Conditional View allows you to show or hide an element dynamically based on the evaluation of a condition expression.

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of the OmniScript Step element?

answers.text: To group related elements and create navigation

questions.explanation: Step elements organize OmniScript into logical sections and provide navigation between different parts of the script.

questions.question_text: How can you pass data from an OmniScript to a DataRaptor?

answers.text: Using the DataRaptor Post Action element

questions.explanation: The DataRaptor Post Action element is used to pass data from an OmniScript to a DataRaptor for processing.

questions.question_text: What is the difference between 'Required' and 'Required at Runtime' for an OmniScript element?

answers.text: Required validates on save, Required at Runtime validates on navigation
Required at Runtime only applies in LWC
Required is for design time, Required at Runtime is for execution

questions.explanation: Required validates when saving the OmniScript, while Required at Runtime validates when the user attempts to navigate to the next step.

questions.question_text: Which element would you use to display a list of records with checkboxes for selection?
questions.explanation: The Table element can display multiple records with checkboxes, allowing users to select one or more rows.

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of the 'Send JSON Path' property in a DataRaptor Action?

answers.text: To specify which data to send to the DataRaptor

questions.explanation: Send JSON Path specifies which portion of the OmniScript data should be passed to the DataRaptor for processing.

questions.question_text: Which of these can trigger a calculation in a Formula element? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Formula elements recalculate when dependent field values change (user input) and on initial page load. They don't automatically recalculate on navigation or DataRaptor responses without field changes.

questions.question_text: What is the recommended way to handle errors in an OmniScript?

answers.text: Use Try-Catch blocks in custom JavaScript
Configure error handling in Integration Procedures

questions.explanation: The recommended approach is to handle errors in Integration Procedures, which provide built-in error handling capabilities and conditional paths.

questions.question_text: What is the main advantage of using an Integration Procedure instead of directly calling Apex from an OmniScript?
questions.explanation: Integration Procedures provide a declarative way to orchestrate data operations that can be reused across multiple OmniScripts and FlexCards without writing code.

questions.question_text: Which Integration Procedure action would you use to call an external REST API?
questions.explanation: HTTP Action is specifically designed to make callouts to external REST APIs from Integration Procedures.

questions.question_text: In an Integration Procedure, what is the purpose of the Response JSON Path?

answers.text: To format the final output structure
To extract specific data from action responses

questions.explanation: Response JSON Path is used to extract specific portions of data from an action's response and make it available to subsequent actions.

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of the 'Execution Conditional Formula' in an Integration Procedure action?

answers.text: To determine if the action should execute

questions.explanation: Execution Conditional Formula determines whether an action should execute based on a conditional expression. If false, the action is skipped.

questions.question_text: How can you pass data between actions in an Integration Procedure?

answers.text: Through the Response JSON Path and subsequent action inputs

questions.explanation: Data flows between actions using Response JSON Path to extract data from one action and map it as input to subsequent actions.

questions.question_text: Which of the following actions can be used in an Integration Procedure? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Integration Procedures support DataRaptor actions, Apex actions, Set Values for data manipulation, and Delete Actions for record deletion.

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of the 'Cache' property in an Integration Procedure?

answers.text: To store results for faster subsequent calls
To persist data across user sessions

questions.explanation: Enabling cache stores the Integration Procedure results temporarily, improving performance by avoiding redundant server calls with the same inputs.

questions.question_text: How do you handle conditional branching in an Integration Procedure?

answers.text: Use Conditional Action with branch paths
Use Execution Conditional Formula on actions

questions.explanation: Conditional branching is achieved using Execution Conditional Formula on individual actions, which determines whether they execute based on data conditions.

questions.question_text: What is the difference between 'Input/Output' and 'Execution Options' in an Integration Procedure element?

answers.text: Input/Output defines data flow, Execution Options controls when/how the action runs
Input/Output is for design time, Execution Options is for runtime
Input/Output is mandatory, Execution Options is optional

questions.explanation: Input/Output defines what data goes into and comes out of an action. Execution Options controls conditional execution, error handling, and other runtime behaviors.

questions.question_text: Can an Integration Procedure call another Integration Procedure?

answers.text: Yes, using the Integration Procedure Action
Yes, but only in preview mode

questions.explanation: Integration Procedures can call other Integration Procedures using the Integration Procedure Action, enabling modular and reusable designs.

questions.question_text: What is a FlexCard state used for?

answers.text: To define different layouts for different screen sizes
To show different content based on conditions

questions.explanation: FlexCard states allow you to show different content, layouts, or actions based on data conditions, providing dynamic card behavior.

questions.question_text: Which of the following data sources can FlexCards use? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: FlexCards can use Integration Procedures and DataRaptors as data sources. Direct SOQL queries and Apex classes are not supported data sources.

questions.question_text: Which FlexCard action type would you use to navigate to a record page?
questions.explanation: Navigation Action is specifically designed to handle navigation to record pages, URLs, and other Salesforce pages.

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of the 'Flyout' in a FlexCard?

answers.text: To display additional details when the card is clicked

questions.explanation: A Flyout provides a way to display additional information or actions in an overlay when a user interacts with the FlexCard.

questions.question_text: How can you pass data from a FlexCard to an OmniScript?

answers.text: Through a Navigation Action with parameters

questions.explanation: Data can be passed from a FlexCard to an OmniScript using a Navigation Action configured with input parameters.

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of the 'Test Data' feature in FlexCard designer?

answers.text: To preview the card with sample data

questions.explanation: Test Data allows you to provide sample JSON data to preview how the FlexCard will render with actual data during design time.

questions.question_text: Which element would you add to a FlexCard to display a clickable button?
questions.explanation: Action elements in FlexCards are rendered as clickable buttons that can trigger various actions like navigation, events, or data updates.

questions.question_text: Can FlexCards be used in Experience Cloud sites?
questions.explanation: FlexCards can be published as Lightning Web Components and used in Experience Cloud sites, Lightning pages, and other contexts.

questions.question_text: What is the recommended approach for displaying a list of records in FlexCards?

answers.text: Use the repeater functionality with a data source returning arrays

questions.explanation: FlexCards have built-in repeater functionality that automatically displays multiple cards when the data source returns an array of records.

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of the OmniStudio Designer role?

answers.text: To create and modify OmniStudio components
To deploy OmniStudio components to production

questions.explanation: The OmniStudio Designer role grants permissions to create, edit, and configure OmniStudio components like OmniScripts, DataRaptors, and Integration Procedures.

questions.question_text: Which statement about OmniStudio LWC (Lightning Web Components) is correct?

answers.text: OmniScripts can only be deployed as LWC in Experience Cloud
LWC OmniScripts have better performance than standard OmniScripts
FlexCards cannot be deployed as LWC
DataRaptors require LWC deployment to function

questions.explanation: LWC-based OmniScripts typically have better performance and load times compared to the standard JavaScript-based implementation.

questions.question_text: What is the recommended way to migrate OmniStudio components between orgs?

answers.text: Use Change Sets or DevOps tools

questions.explanation: The recommended approach is to use Salesforce Change Sets or DevOps tools like Salesforce CLI for proper version control and deployment.

questions.question_text: Which package must be installed to use OmniStudio in a Salesforce org?
questions.explanation: OmniStudio (or Vlocity OmniStudio for older implementations) must be installed as a managed package to use OmniStudio components.

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of versioning in OmniStudio components?

answers.text: To track changes and enable rollback

questions.explanation: Versioning allows you to maintain multiple versions of OmniStudio components, track changes over time, and rollback to previous versions if needed.

questions.question_text: When should you activate an OmniStudio component?

answers.text: After testing and before making it available to end users

questions.explanation: Components should be activated after thorough testing and validation, as activation makes the component available for use by end users.

questions.question_text: What happens when you deactivate an OmniStudio component?

answers.text: It becomes unavailable for use but remains in the system

questions.explanation: Deactivating a component makes it unavailable for end-user use but preserves it in the system. It can be reactivated without redeployment.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is true about OmniStudio namespaces? (Select all that apply)

answers.text: They organize components by business function
They are required for all components

questions.explanation: Namespaces prevent naming conflicts and help organize components logically by business function. They're not always required and don't affect performance.

questions.question_text: What is the maximum number of levels deep you can traverse relationships in a DataRaptor Extract?
questions.explanation: DataRaptor Extract allows traversing up to 5 levels of object relationships, following Salesforce API limitations.

questions.question_text: How do you filter records in a DataRaptor Extract?

answers.text: Using WHERE clause in the Filter tab

questions.explanation: DataRaptor Extract provides a Filter tab where you can specify filter conditions similar to WHERE clauses to limit which records are retrieved.

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of 'Response JSON Node' in a DataRaptor Post Action?

answers.text: To specify where to store the DataRaptor response in the data JSON

questions.explanation: Response JSON Node specifies the path in the OmniScript's data JSON where the DataRaptor response should be stored.

questions.question_text: Can you embed one OmniScript inside another?
questions.explanation: OmniScripts can be embedded within other OmniScripts using the OmniScript element, enabling modular and reusable designs.

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of the 'Save for Later' feature in OmniScripts?

answers.text: To automatically save progress every 5 minutes
To allow users to pause and resume later

questions.explanation: Save for Later allows users to save their progress in an OmniScript and return to complete it later, improving user experience for long forms.

questions.question_text: What is a Response Cache Key in an Integration Procedure?

answers.text: A unique identifier for cached responses based on input parameters
An encryption key for secure responses
A field that triggers cache invalidation
A timeout setting for cache expiration

questions.explanation: Response Cache Key is used to create a unique identifier based on input parameters, ensuring that cached responses are retrieved only when inputs match.

questions.question_text: How do you handle loops or iterations in an Integration Procedure?
questions.explanation: Integration Procedures support the Loop Block element, which allows iterating over arrays or collections of data.

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of the 'Publish' button in FlexCard designer?

answers.text: To make the FlexCard available as an LWC

questions.explanation: Publishing a FlexCard generates the Lightning Web Component code, making it available for use in Lightning pages, communities, and other contexts.

questions.question_text: Can FlexCards display data without a data source?

answers.text: No, a data source is always required
Yes, using static content and manual data entry

questions.explanation: FlexCards can receive data from their parent component (like another FlexCard or an OmniScript) without requiring their own data source.

questions.question_text: What is the difference between 'Preview' and 'Activate' for an OmniScript?

answers.text: Preview is for testing, Activate makes it available to users
Preview shows design view, Activate shows runtime view

questions.explanation: Preview allows you to test the OmniScript in a safe environment. Activate publishes it and makes it available to end users with appropriate permissions.

questions.question_text: What happens when you enable 'Is this Required?' for a field in a DataRaptor Load?

answers.text: The field must have a value or the load fails
The field is marked as required in Salesforce
A validation error is shown to the user
The field gets a default value if empty

questions.explanation: Marking a field as required in DataRaptor Load means the operation will fail if that field doesn't have a value in the input data.

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of the 'Aggregate' function in OmniScript formulas?

answers.text: To perform calculations on arrays of data

questions.explanation: The Aggregate function allows performing calculations like SUM, AVG, MIN, MAX on arrays or collections of data in OmniScript formulas.

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of the 'Delete' action in an Integration Procedure?
questions.explanation: The Delete action in Integration Procedures is used to delete Salesforce records based on record IDs provided in the input.

questions.question_text: How can you customize the styling of a FlexCard?

answers.text: Through the FlexCard designer's styling properties

questions.explanation: FlexCards can be styled using the designer's built-in styling properties, custom CSS classes, and Lightning Design System tokens for consistent theming.

questions.question_text: What is the recommended approach for debugging OmniStudio components?

answers.text: Use browser developer console and Debug Mode

questions.explanation: The recommended approach is to enable Debug Mode in OmniStudio and use the browser's developer console to view detailed logs and debug information.
